blog.description: Multi-fandom blog (as well as other random stuff). Content changes depending on what's on my dash, what tags I'm on and what I'm currently into, and my activity is extremely irregular, so I apologise in advanced

i have a whole ass list of weird shit people have said
and some characters had multiple lines that could have fit them
but these ones were the ones that fit best so
summary: Avengers as shit me and my friends have said
body:
Avengers as shit me and my friends have said

Tony: Destroy your nervous system so that you don’t feel anything

Clint: I can’t hear you. I’ve gone blind in my ears

Natasha: Shooting lasers from your dick ISN’T a power!

Thor: I didn’t know about your tangerine fetish

Steve: And then they had the AUDACITY to charge me 25p for a MUSHROOM

Bruce: What do you mean fire resistant? It’s made of fucking ice!

BONUS

Peter P: To win, you must yeet, beat, and defeat

summary: Transform
body:
Transform

“Sorcery is really just the art of borrowing, breaking down matter that already exists, playing with it, and transforming it into something new.”

Stephen watched, a rather content smile on his face, a half-drunken bottle of beer held in a metallic hand. Tony’s hair was wild, his eyes bright and sharp. He cupped his hands in front of the doctor, leaving a bubble of space between his palms.

“Take the air, for example,” Tony began, grinning wide. “It’s made of oxygen, nitrogen, some carbon dioxide, argon, and methane. If I focus on one of those, drawing it out from the very air while also adjusting its state…”

His eyes fluttered a little. A bubble of liquid slowly appeared between his hands, steadily growing from nothing. As it formed, waves of vapor swirled around it, trickling down his fingers to the floor. Stephen watched, mystified. 

“Ta daah,” Tony’s eyes crinkled with delight. “Liquid nitrogen. And here–”

The nitrogen vanished, evaporating back into the air. Tony plucked up a nearby pencil, holding it up for emphasis.

“This happens to be a pure graphite pencil. Someone here’s got some standards, I dunno, but it’s definitely not me–”

Stephen snickered into his fist. His cheeks were flushed, a dopey grin on his face. Tony swallowed thickly. Now was a bad time to get distracted.

“Graphite is made of carbon, yes?” The sorcerer continued. “So if I borrow the carbon in the pencil and some kinetic energy, using magic to boost the output and also apply some ambient heat–”

Tony crushed the pencil between his hands, pressing as firmly as he could. His palms glowed, bright and hot, before abiding. He pulled his hand back and, when the wood and metal and rubber burned away, he was left with a tiny diamond in his palm. Stephen gasped, maybe a little too dramatically, and held the diamond between his thumb and index finger.

“That’s incredible,” He gushed, holding it up to the light. “It’s really fascinating how well thought out your sorcery is. I assumed it’s more… Raw and emotional, but you’ve really just reduced it to good ol’ scientific methods and analytics.”

“It just makes more sense that way.” Tony shrugged, leaning back against a desk.

They stood there in companionable silence, the Sanctum’s backdrop rather cozy and familiar. Out the corner of his eye, he watched Tony, taking in his relaxed body language, his open smile, his warmth and companionable attitude. He was different here, surrounded by magic, living in it. Something in him seemed calmer. Stephen wondered if he was the same back in his weapons design days, just as relaxed surrounded by missile casings and gunpowder.

“Watcha thinkin’ about?” Tony spoke up, his voice soft.

Stephen inhaled slowly, holding it in his lungs until it burned.

“… About how I’ll need at least another one of these,” He held up his nearly empty beer bottle, smiling. “If you’re gonna show me some more mind-melting magic stuffs.”

Tony winked and the bottle refilled itself, earning a huff and a grin in return.

“Easy peasy, doc.”

summary: Broken
title: Broken
body:
"Tony, you have a visitor.“

               Tony Stark looked up from the paper he was reviewing at the sound of his wife, giving her a wave as his eyes traveled back down to what he was working on. "Send them in, unless they’re some big shot newspaper company. I don’t need any more journalists-”

               "Mr. Stark,“ a voice interrupted, entirely too cheerful and out of place in Tony’s office. But it still made the man break into a smile as he pushed the papers away and stood up from his chair.

               "Peter,” he greeted, rounding the desk to wrap his arms around the teen, hugging him tightly to his chest. The boy had broken into a relieved smile, hugging him back with one arm around his broad frame, the other hidden behind his back. Tony didn’t seem to notice, patting Peter on the back and then holding him at arms length, getting a good look at him. “How’s school been, kid? You passing all of your classes?”

               Peter nods, offering the same, almost hesitant smile Tony had seen before. He didn’t press for answers quite yet, taking his time as he went back to his chair, plopping down almost ungracefully. “Yeah, I’m top of all my classes. My English teacher thinks that I could apply for this really big scholarship through the school where they would basically pay for my whole first year.” Peter’s eyes practically light up at the thought, before they dimmed quickly. “But I don’t think I’m going to apply for it.”

               Tony’s forehead scrunched in confusion, watching the boy. “Why not? I’m sure you’d get it, kid, you’re smart enough.”

               "I know.“ The boy fidgets in his spot a little, glancing at a chair for a brief moment but remains standing. Tony opens his mouth to ask about it, but Peter keeps talking. "It would only cover one year. I’d have to drop out after that, and it would be unfair to someone else who needs to scholarship.”

               "Drop out? What for, kid? You planning to get pregnant mid semester?“ Tony jokes, laughing at himself. Peter huffs slightly, and the corners of his mouth curve upwards, but he doesn’t give the smile that Tony secretly likes to see.

               "I can’t afford to go to college,” Peter explains, almost sadly. “Besides, I’m too busy being-” he glances around briefly, as if to make sure no one was listening before continuing “-Spiderman. I wouldn’t have time to do my studies and to get a job. Like, a paid job. I don’t want to live with aunt May forever and keep draining her income to take care of me. She deserves better than that. I need to get myself an apartment and I can’t do that if I’m going to college.”

               Tony watches Peter for a moment, studying him as if he were a puzzle, complex and indecipherable. “Okay, then I’ll pay for college.”

               Across the desk, Peter gaped at him, like it was the craziest thing he had ever heard. It was enough of a shock that the boy brought his other arm out from behind his back, and then it was Tony’s turn to gape.

               "Peter, oh my god, what happened?“ He was up and out of his seat in a flash, rounding the desk in three steps before he was at the boy’s side, grabbing his arm before Peter could protest. "Pete, this is broken.” The arm was bent mid forearm, the pieces of bone pressed against opposite sides of the boy’s arm. Tony ran his thumb over the break in the bone, and Peter hissed, weakly trying to pull it back.

               "It’s nothing, Mr. Stark. Just a minor injury.“

               "Minor? You call this minor?” Tony snipped, outraged that something like this had happened. “How did you break it?”

               Peter seemed hesitant, but Tony didn’t push, letting the boy get there on his own. “Mr. Stark,” Peter started, trailing off for a moment. He took a deep breath before lifting his eyes off the ground and to the other man’s face. “I was practicing some cool new flips and swings and I accidentally undershot how far away a building was. I landed on my arm and broke it.”

               Tony scowled, face scrunching up. “Bullshit.” He called, trying hard not to either accidentally hurt the kid by squeezing or scare him by yelling. “Tell me the truth. What really happened?”

               "Mr. Stark, really, I don’t think it’s that big of a deal. Why can’t we just forget about it?“

               "If it wasn’t that big of a deal, why didn’t you go to the hospital and get it fixed up? Peter, it can’t fix itself like this! It needs to be in a cast.”

               "Some kid pushed me down the stairs at school, okay?“ Peter interrupted, his face bright red, though with anger or embarrassment, Tony wasn’t sure. "He’s been picking on me for a few weeks now, and he pushed me down the stairs and I broke my arm but I didn’t want to tell anyone because then they’ll just laugh at me and I just want to make it through the last month without any issues.”

               Tony was shocked, his mouth hanging open. Bullied? Peter Parker? It didn’t seem possible, but the boy in front of him refused to meet his eyes, and Tony knew he wasn’t lying this time. He gently set Peter’s arm down by his side, then grabbed his keys off his desk.

               "Come on, kid, we’re going to get this fixed, and don’t worry, I’m paying for it.“

               Tony set a hand on Peter’s shoulder, steering him carefully out of the room and towards the garage. Peter didn’t even protest, just relaxing under the man’s hand and allowing himself to be led. Tony couldn’t imagine the pain he was in, or how he could go this long without breaking down even a little bit.

               "As soon as we get in the car, I’ll call aunt May and let her know what’s going-”

               "No!“ Peter cried, eyes wide and frantic as he turned to the other man. "Mr. Stark, please, don’t tell her about the other kids. I don’t want to worry her. Please, Mr. Stark.”

               One look in Peter’s large, doe eyes, and Tony gave a sigh, caving easily. It was hard to say no to the boy, and he wondered how in the world the other kids had the heart to push him down the stairs. “Alright, alright, I won’t tell her about the other kids. But I’m still going to tell her that your arm is broken. She has a right to know.”

               Peter nodded, giving that soft, almost gummy smile that Tony liked to see before he winced, rubbing over his arm lightly. Tony pulled the boy close to his side, hooking an arm over his shoulder.

               "Okay, tough guy, let’s go get you patched up.“

               "Drop out? What for, kid? You planning to get pregnant mid semester?“ Tony jokes, laughing at himself. Peter huffs slightly, and the corners of his mouth curve upwards, but he doesn’t give the smile that Tony secretly likes to see.

               "I can’t afford to go to college,” Peter explains, almost sadly. “Besides, I’m too busy being-” he glances around briefly, as if to make sure no one was listening before continuing “-Spiderman. I wouldn’t have time to do my studies and to get a job. Like, a paid job. I don’t want to live with aunt May forever and keep draining her income to take care of me. She deserves better than that. I need to get myself an apartment and I can’t do that if I’m going to college.”

               Tony watches Peter for a moment, studying him as if he were a puzzle, complex and indecipherable. “Okay, then I’ll pay for college.”

               Across the desk, Peter gaped at him, like it was the craziest thing he had ever heard. It was enough of a shock that the boy brought his other arm out from behind his back, and then it was Tony’s turn to gape.

               "Peter, oh my god, what happened?“ He was up and out of his seat in a flash, rounding the desk in three steps before he was at the boy’s side, grabbing his arm before Peter could protest. "Pete, this is broken.” The arm was bent mid forearm, the pieces of bone pressed against opposite sides of the boy’s arm. Tony ran his thumb over the break in the bone, and Peter hissed, weakly trying to pull it back.

               "It’s nothing, Mr. Stark. Just a minor injury.“

               "Minor? You call this minor?” Tony snipped, outraged that something like this had happened. “How did you break it?”

               Peter seemed hesitant, but Tony didn’t push, letting the boy get there on his own. “Mr. Stark,” Peter started, trailing off for a moment. He took a deep breath before lifting his eyes off the ground and to the other man’s face. “I was practicing some cool new flips and swings and I accidentally undershot how far away a building was. I landed on my arm and broke it.”

               Tony scowled, face scrunching up. “Bullshit.” He called, trying hard not to either accidentally hurt the kid by squeezing or scare him by yelling. “Tell me the truth. What really happened?”

               "Mr. Stark, really, I don’t think it’s that big of a deal. Why can’t we just forget about it?“

               "If it wasn’t that big of a deal, why didn’t you go to the hospital and get it fixed up? Peter, it can’t fix itself like this! It needs to be in a cast.”

               "Some kid pushed me down the stairs at school, okay?“ Peter interrupted, his face bright red, though with anger or embarrassment, Tony wasn’t sure. "He’s been picking on me for a few weeks now, and he pushed me down the stairs and I broke my arm but I didn’t want to tell anyone because then they’ll just laugh at me and I just want to make it through the last month without any issues.”

               Tony was shocked, his mouth hanging open. Bullied? Peter Parker? It didn’t seem possible, but the boy in front of him refused to meet his eyes, and Tony knew he wasn’t lying this time. He gently set Peter’s arm down by his side, then grabbed his keys off his desk.

               "Come on, kid, we’re going to get this fixed, and don’t worry, I’m paying for it.“

               Tony set a hand on Peter’s shoulder, steering him carefully out of the room and towards the garage. Peter didn’t even protest, just relaxing under the man’s hand and allowing himself to be led. Tony couldn’t imagine the pain he was in, or how he could go this long without breaking down even a little bit.

               "As soon as we get in the car, I’ll call aunt May and let her know what’s going-”

               "No!“ Peter cried, eyes wide and frantic as he turned to the other man. "Mr. Stark, please, don’t tell her about the other kids. I don’t want to worry her. Please, Mr. Stark.”

               One look in Peter’s large, doe eyes, and Tony gave a sigh, caving easily. It was hard to say no to the boy, and he wondered how in the world the other kids had the heart to push him down the stairs. “Alright, alright, I won’t tell her about the other kids. But I’m still going to tell her that your arm is broken. She has a right to know.”

               Peter nodded, giving that soft, almost gummy smile that Tony liked to see before he winced, rubbing over his arm lightly. Tony pulled the boy close to his side, hooking an arm over his shoulder.

               "Okay, tough guy, let’s go get you patched up.“

"Tony, you have a visitor.“

               "Mr. Stark,“ a voice interrupted, entirely too cheerful and out of place in Tony’s office. But it still made the man break into a smile as he pushed the papers away and stood up from his chair.

               "Peter,” he greeted, rounding the desk to wrap his arms around the teen, hugging him tightly to his chest. The boy had broken into a relieved smile, hugging him back with one arm around his broad frame, the other hidden behind his back. Tony didn’t seem to notice, patting Peter on the back and then holding him at arms length, getting a good look at him. “How’s school been, kid? You passing all of your classes?”

summary: Gunshot Wounds and Geometry Tests
title: Gunshot Wounds and Geometry Tests
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2WJ8IVB

by OnceUponaFangirl

“What the hell, kid?” Each word is punctuated and Peter’s pretty sure he wasn’t even this angry after the ferry incident. “Care to explain why you’re here and not in the fucking hospital that I left you in a few hours ago?”

“I-I-uh,” It was rare that Tony allowed himself to curse so freely around Peter, especially in a public setting like this. Though Peter was pretty sure that had more to do with Pepper scolding him than Tony’s desire to be a good influence on him. (Both definitely played a factor.) “I had a test today.“

summary: The Russos are finally saying some sensible things 🙄🙄 Don't think this makes up for the other weirdness they've said but it’s a...
body:
The Russos are finally saying some sensible things 🙄🙄 Don’t think this makes up for the other weirdness they’ve said but it’s a start…

“Avengers: Endgame co-directors Joe and Anthony Russo say that Tony Stark was right about his mentality leading to the creation of Ultron in Avengers: Age of Ultron.”

“Stark received a lot of heat for Ultron, and that mistake haunted him for years. It was one of the reasons why the Sokovia Accords was introduced leading to his conflict with Captain America and the eventual break up of the Avengers in Captain America: Civil War.”

“In hindsight, Stark has always been right about the threat coming. For years, he’s been painted as the MCU’s quasi-villain and despite his coy attitude, he was always at the forefront of every battle to protect Earth. Even when the Avengers broke up and the majority of the heroes sided with Captain America, he continued work on his tech, preparing for any possible attack.”


From this article

summary: I need a parallel gifset between Oliver Queen and Tony Stark. Because these guys: are rich brats turned into selfless heroes...
body:
I need a parallel gifset between Oliver Queen and Tony Stark. Because these guys:

  • are rich brats turned into selfless heroes
  • married brilliant women who were once thought to be simply their secretaries
  • had beautiful daughters
  • are extremely loyal to their friends
  • were haunted by their parents’ deaths

and last but not least… spoiler alert

sacrificed their lives for the freakin’ universe

tags: this is so friggin entertaining tho
summary: Tbh it’s so entertaining
body:
Tbh it’s so entertaining

Watching the salty and bitter Marvel fans rant and rave about how the Russo’s are horrible people and deserve to lose their careers just because their two favorite characters died. Yes, neither of those characters deserved to die, but I guess real life isn’t all rainbows and Happily Ever Afters, huh?

summary: Endgame 2.0
title: Endgame 2.0
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2WHaJS4

by Sapphire_of_SHIELD

Peter Parker remembers it all.
Remembers aliens, Titan, Thanos, the stones.
Remembers every atom in his body splitting, and the agony that followed.
Remembers looking up at his mentor’s grief-stricken eyes and muttering a small ‘I’m sorry’ before he was one with the wind.
He was gone.
But now he has the chance to take that all back.
Today, Peter Parker can make a difference.

About:A collector of geekery and whimsy, this tumblr is a mish-mash of BJD, Fandom, Craftiness, and Art appreciation. Currently obsessed with all things MCU. Current Ships: Stucky, Stony, Steam, Winterhawk, Winterwidow, Barbershop Quartet, and others.

White-Privileged and trying to do better, please feel free to educate and inform me if I do otherwise.
